== Life and career ==

section: == Life and career ==
== Life and career == | === 1971–94: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: 1971–94: Early life and career beginnings =
section: == Life and career == | === 1971–94: Early life and career beginnings ===
== Life and career == | === 1971–94: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Jose Roberto Pulido Jr. was born on April 25, 1971, in Edinburg, Texas.
section: == Life and career == | === 1971–94: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: He is the youngest child of Roberto Pulido, an award-winning Tejano music singer; and Diana Montes, daughter of Tejano musician Mario Montes.
section: == Life and career == | === 1971–94: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Known as Bobby Pulido, he attended Edinburg High School and joined the school's mariachi group before joining his father's band Los Clásicos as their saxophonist and backup vocalist.
section: == Life and career == | === 1971–94: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: In 1994, EMI Latin released a compilation album titled Branding Icons, which featured Pulido with his father on the song "Contigo".
section: == Life and career == | === 1971–94: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Pulido was accepted at St. Mary's University, where he studied business management as his major.
section: == Life and career == | === 1971–94: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: After the album's release in 1994, he decided to leave college and pursue a singing career in the Tejano market, during what is now known as the genre's golden age.
section: == Life and career == | === 1971–94: Early life and career beginnings ===
== Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success =
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===
== Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: Pulido started his own band with guitarist Gilbert Trejo, bassist Mike Fox, drummer and cousin Jimmy Montes, keyboardist Rey Gutierrez, and Frank Caballero serving as the band's accordionist.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: Initially, Pulido received criticism from veteran Tejano musicians, who believed the singer was "riding on the hard-earned reputation" of his father's established music career.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: In May 1995, Pulido signed a recording contract with EMI Latin and released his debut album Desvelado that September.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: Then-president of EMI Latin Jose Behar told Billboard the company had "high hopes" for the singer in the country music market.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: His debut single "No Se Por Que" peaked at number 33 on the United States Billboard Hot Latin Tracks chart in December 1995.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: Desvelado debuted at number 44 on the U.S. Billboard Top Latin Albums chart, the title track was second single released and debuted at number 21 on the U.S. Billboard Hot Latin Tracks chart in the week of February 3, 1996, and Pulido became a popular Tejano recording artist.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: In April 1996, the album peaked at number nine on the Top Latin Albums chart and number three on the U.S. Billboard Regional Mexican Albums chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: John Lannert of Billboard magazine called Pulido's chart position "impressive" and called the singer a "fast-rising artist".
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: It was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) the same year, signifying shipments of 100,000 units in the U.S.  Pulido ended 1996 as the eighth best-selling regional Mexican artist and Desvelado ended the year as the eleventh best-selling regional Mexican album.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: The album reached sales of 100,000 units by the end of 1999.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: At the 1996 Tejano Music Awards, Pulido tied first place with Eddie Gonzales for Best New Rising Male Tejano Artists.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: In July 1996, Pulido married Eliza Anzaldua and took a short career hiatus.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: He continued promoting his second studio album Enséñame, which was released a month after his marriage.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: Billboard called Enséñame a "rousing" ranchera and "infectious" cumbia-flavored recording, and said it believed Pulido was aiming to follow Emilio Navaira, who wanted to crossover and become a country music artist.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: Ramiro Burr of the San Antonio Express-News said Pulido's vocals were "much improved" over his previous work.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: Enséñame peaked at number ten on the U.S. Billboard Top Latin Albums and number two on the U.S. Billboard Regional Mexican Albums chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: It also produced three top-twenty Regional Mexican Airplay tracks; "Enséñame", "Se Murió De Amor", and "La Rosa".
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: The album earned Pulido a nomination for the Tejano Music Award for Male Entertainer of the Year and the Lo Nuestro Award for Regional Mexican New Artist of the Year.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: Pulido along with Mexican singer Graciela Beltrán, American urban quintets the Barrio Boyzz, Tejano musicians Emilio Navaira, Pete Astudillo, and Jennifer Peña recorded "Viviras Selena" for the 1997 soundtrack to the biopic film about Selena, who was called the Queen of Tejano music and was killed in March 1995.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: By 1997, Pulido was being credited for introducing Tejano music to a much younger audience in the U.S., among other Tejano novitiates.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: In 1998, Pulido released his third studio album Llegaste a Mi Vida, which peaked at number two on the Regional Mexican Albums chart and at number eleven on the Top Latin Albums chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: The only single to appear on the Latin singles chart, "Pedire", peaked at number 28 on the Hot Latin Tracks chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: Pulido's album won five of twelve nominations at the 1998 Tejano Music Awards; winning Male Vocalist of the Year, Male Entertainer of the Year, Tejano Crossover Song of the Year for "¿Dónde Estás?", and Tejano Album of the Year.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: The same year, Desvelado and Llegaste a Mi Vida, each sold 100,000 units in Mexico—an unprecedented milestone for the singer.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: In September 1998, Pulido released his first live album En Vivo: Desde Monterrey Mexico, which was recorded on April 24, 1998, The album became the singer's fourth top-ten U.S. recording and peaked at number 21 on the Top Latin Albums chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: in a sold-out concert at the Auditorio Coca-Cola in Monterrey, becoming the first Tejano grupo musician to do so.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: In March 1999, he released his fourth studio album El Cazador, which produced the top-thirty Regional Mexican Airplay single "Cantarle a Ella".
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: Pulido became the youngest recipient to be awarded the Orgullo de la Frontera from the Fiestas Mexicanas in February 1999.
section: == Life and career == | === 1995–99: Debut album and commercial success ===

sentences: In an April 1999 interview, Pulido expressed interest in recording a Latin pop album and said he was not interested in crossing over and recording English-language albums.

== Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus =
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===
== Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: By 2000, Tejano music's dwindling popularity was thought to have recovered but it failed to do so; music critics believed veteran Tejano artists such as Emilio Navaira, Selena, Mazz, Michael Salgado, and Pulido dominated the airwaves in the U.S. and that old-school singers were not able to compete.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: That year, Pulido became a teen idol among Mexican American teenage girls and one of the most influential Tejano recording artists to the same demographic.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: In March 2000, he released Zona de Peligro, which was less successful than his previous albums, peaking at number 48 on the Top Latin Albums chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: None of its singles were commercially successful, but Pulido won the Tejano Music Award for Male Entertainer of the Year—his third consecutive win.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: According to musicologist Guadalupe San Miguel, Tejano musicians beginning in the late 20th century and into the early 21st century were indistinguishable from each other.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: Pulido released his sixth studio album Siempre Pensando En Ti in March 2001; it fared less well commercially, peaking at number 50 on the Top Latin Albums chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: The album became Pulido's last recording to impact a music chart on Billboard.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: In 2002, Pulido organized the Celebrity Golf Classic, a benefit charity that raised US$50,000 for the Easter Seals program.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: McAllen mayor Leo Montalvo announced at the event that November 2, 2002, would be "Bobby Pulido Day".
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: That June, Pulido released an eponymous album titled Bobby, which spawned the top 40 U.S. single "Vanidosa" that failed to appear on any music chart and was his final single.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: He recorded a cover version of Mexican singer Juan Gabriel's 1999 single "Se Me Olvidó Otra Vez", which was included on Bobby.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: His next albums, Montame (2003) and Vive (2005), failed to chart, ending his eight-year presence on Billboard.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: In 2003, Pulido made his acting debut in the telenovela television movie La Decada Furiosa, in which he played himself.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: Two years later, he appeared as a guest on the reality television show Big Brother México.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–09: Decline in popularity, acting debut, and hiatus ===

sentences: Pulido performed and recorded "Ya Ves" for the live televised tribute concert Selena ¡VIVE!

== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Pulido married Eliza Anzaldua in July 1996.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: They had three sons; Remy Pulido (born 1996), Darian Pulido (born 1998), and Trey Pulido (born 2005).
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: However, Pulido filed for divorce in September 2013, after 17 years of being married and four months of separation.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: He married Mariana Morales in November 2018 and his fourth son Rodrigo Pulido was born December 2019.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: He currently resides in Miami, Florida and enjoys working out, eating healthily, and playing golf; his favorite pastime is playing guitar and he finds composing songs therapeutic.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: During his musical career, Pulido's fans questioned his sexuality; he said he is not homosexual but rumors that he had slept with men continue to circulate.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Pulido spoke to a Mexican television news program in 2013, and told viewers he is straight and that he has gay fans, which he said did not concern him.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: In April 2010, media outlets questioned Pulido after he released a music video in which he plays a stereotypical gay male; the singer said he wanted to "try something different [in his music videos]" and defended his gay followers, saying he has nothing against the LGBT community.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: After Puerto Rican pop singer Ricky Martin publicly announced his homosexuality, Pulido defended Martin's choice, saying "he is living his dreams".
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Pulido has been an outspoken opponent of Republican president of the United States, Donald Trump.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On his Instagram account, Pulido uploaded a picture of himself "urinating" on Trump's star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.
section: == Personal life ==
